title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #255: Discrepancy of Sequences**

**Setup:** z₁, z₂, ... ∈ [0,1] is any infinite sequence.
Discrepancy D_N(I) = #{n ≤ N : zₙ ∈ I} - N·|I|

**Question:** Must some interval have unbounded discrepancy?

**Answer:** YES (Schmidt 1968)
mathContext: Discrepancy measures how far the empirical distribution deviates from uniform. A perfectly uniform sequence would have D_N = 0.

title: Discrepancy
content:
**discrepancy z a b N:**

D_N([a,b]) = #{n ≤ N : zₙ ∈ [a,b]} - N·(b-a)

**Interpretation:**
- D_N > 0: Too many points in the interval
- D_N < 0: Too few points in the interval
- D_N = 0: Exactly the expected number

title: Unbounded Discrepancy
content:
**hasUnboundedDiscrepancy z a b:**

limsup_{N→∞} |D_N([a,b])| = ∞

For any bound M, there exists N with |D_N| > M.

**erdosQuestion:** Does every sequence have such an interval?

title: Schmidt's Theorem (1968)
content:
**schmidt_theorem_1968:**

For ANY sequence in [0,1], there EXISTS an interval I with unbounded discrepancy.

This answers Erdős's question affirmatively. No sequence can have bounded discrepancy on ALL intervals.

title: No Uniform Bound
content:
**no_uniformly_bounded_discrepancy:**

There is NO sequence with bounded discrepancy on all intervals.

**Proof:** By contradiction using Schmidt's theorem. If a sequence had bounded discrepancy everywhere, Schmidt would give an interval violating this.

title: Schmidt's Strengthening (1972)
content:
**schmidt_theorem_1972:**

For any sequence, ALL but COUNTABLY MANY intervals [0,x] have unbounded discrepancy.

**Implication:** Uncountably many intervals have unbounded discrepancy. The 'bad' intervals are rare.

title: Tijdeman-Wagner Theorem
content:
**tijdeman_wagner_theorem (1980):**

For almost all x ∈ [0,1]:
limsup |D_N([0,x))| / log N ≫ 1

The discrepancy grows at least logarithmically for almost every interval.

This is the optimal result!

title: Optimality: Van der Corput
content:
**van_der_corput_sequence_exists:**

There exists a sequence where |D_N([0,x))| = O(log N) for ALL x.

**Implication:** Tijdeman-Wagner's log N lower bound is OPTIMAL.

The van der Corput sequence achieves the best possible discrepancy bound.

title: Connections
content:
**isUniformlyDistributed z:**

D_N([0,x))/N → 0 for all x.

**Weyl's Theorem:** (nα) mod 1 is uniformly distributed iff α is irrational.

**Note:** Even uniformly distributed sequences have UNBOUNDED |D_N|!

title: Summary: SOLVED (YES)
content:
**erdos_255:**

**STATUS:** SOLVED (Answer: YES)

**Schmidt (1968):** Some interval has unbounded discrepancy

**Schmidt (1972):** Uncountably many intervals

**Tijdeman-Wagner (1980):** |D_N| ≫ log N for almost all intervals

**Van der Corput:** |D_N| = O(log N) is achievable

**Conclusion:** Logarithmic growth is optimal
